title: Type coercion of tuples of arrays vs. slices in if/else
body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
let s = Some(b"abc".split_at(1));
let a = if let Some(x) = s { x } else { (b"a", b"b") };
```

This happened:
```
error[E0308]: `if` and `else` have incompatible types
 --> src/main.rs:2:41
  |
2 | let a = if let Some(x) = s { x } else { (b"a", b"b") };
  |                              -          ^^^^^^^^^^^^ expected slice `[u8]`, found array `[u8; 1]`
  |                              |
  |                              expected because of this
  |
  = note: expected type `(&[u8], &[u8])`
            found tuple `(&[u8; 1], &[u8; 1])`
```

It would have been convenient if it weren't an error. Similar code does work without a tuple:
```rust
let s : Option<&[u8]> = Some(b"abc");
let a = if let Some(x) = s { x } else { b"a" };
```
or in functional form:
```rust
let s = Some(b"abc".split_at(1));
let a = s.unwrap_or_else(|| (b"a", b"b") );
```
thanks to, I guess coercion. That former example didn't work before 1.9.0, by the way, for a similar reason to why it doesn't work with a tuple now.

### Meta

If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

`rustc --version --verbose`:

```
1.53.0-nightly (2021-03-25 52e3dffa50cfffdcfa14)
```
